questions.text: Match the following complement deficiency with respective diseases.
questions.solution:
Key Takeaways:

  • Early Complement Deficiency (C1, C2, C4)
    Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and collagen vascular diseases.
  • C3 Deficiency
    Recurrent pyogenic infections.
  • C5b-9 (MAC) Deficiency
    Recurrent infections by encapsulated organisms (e.g., pneumococcus, meningococcus).
  • CD55/CD59 Deficiency
    Paroxysmal nocturnal hematuria (PNH).
  • Factor H, I, CD46 Deficiencies
    Atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (aHUS).
  • C1-Esterase Inhibitor Deficiency
    Hereditary angioedema.

questions.text: Which of the following form membrane attack complex and not an anaphylatoxin?
questions.solution:
• Cell lysis :-
    • C5b binds with late components (C6-C9) to form membrane attack complex (MAC; C5b-9)
    • The MAC punches holes in cell membranes of capsulated organism
  • Inflammation :-
    • C5a, 3a, and 4a ( also known as anaphylatoxins) stimulate histamine release from mast cells
    • It causes vasodilation and increase vascular permeability
    • C5a activates lipoxygenase pathway of arachidonic acid metabolism
  • Opsonization
    • Binding of C3b promotes phagocytosis by neutrophils and macrophages through specific C3b receptors.

Key Takeaways: The Membrane Attack Complex (MAC), formed by C5b binding to C6-C9, lyses encapsulated organisms by punching holes in their membranes. Anaphylatoxins (C3a, C4a, C5a) trigger histamine release, causing vasodilation and increased vascular permeability, while C5a also activates the lipoxygenase pathway. C3b aids in opsonization by enhancing phagocytosis through specific receptors, distinguishing it from the roles of MAC and anaphylatoxins.

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution: Key Takeaways: Different tissues have specialized macrophages with unique names: Microglial cells in the brain, Littoral cells in the spleen, Dust cells/alveolar macrophages in the lungs, Kupffer cells in the liver, Hofbauer cells in the placenta, Mesangial cells in the kidney, and Osteoclasts in the bone.

questions.text: Example of fibrinous inflammation from the following is?
questions.solution:
Fibrinous inflammation ( a type of acute inflammation)

When the fibrin content of the fluid exudate is high; e.g. in pneumococcal and rheumatic pericarditis.

Conversion of the fibrinous exudate to scar tissue (organization) within the pericardial sac leads to opaque fibrous thickening of the pericardium and epicardium in the area of exudation and, if the fibrosis is extensive, obliteration of the pericardial space.

Choice A is an example of purulent/suppurative inflammation

Choice C and D are examples of serous inflammation.

Key Takeaways: Fibrinous inflammation occurs when fibrin content in fluid exudate is high, as seen in rheumatic pericarditis and pneumococcal infections. It may lead to fibrous thickening or obliteration of the pericardial space. Examples like acute appendicitis represent purulent inflammation, while blisters in burns and tuberculosis are forms of serous inflammation.

questions.text: Not an example of non-immunological granuloma from the following?
questions.solution:
Key Takeaways:

  • Immunological granulomas are mediated by lymphocytes and include conditions like sarcoidosis, cat scratch disease, tuberculosis, and Hodgkin's lymphoma.
  • Non-immunological granulomas are not lymphocyte-mediated and are caused by physical irritants, such as silicosis and foreign body reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following cytokine promotes eosinophil development from the stem cell?
questions.solution:
Eosinophil

  • They are the most important cells involved in parasitic infections and allergies
  • IL-5 promotes eosinophil development from stem cells
  • Eotaxin is a chemokine for eosinophil
  • They are phagocytic cells for parasites

Key Takeaways: IL-5 promotes eosinophil development from stem cells, playing a crucial role in parasitic infections and allergies. Eosinophils, which are phagocytic cells, help combat parasites. Eotaxin is a chemokine that attracts eosinophils to sites of infection.

questions.text: All are physiological giant cells, except:
questions.solution:
• Physiological giant cells à Osteoclast, syncytio-trophoblast, megakaryocytes
  • Reed Sternberg cell à Hodgkin's lymphoma
  • Touton giant cell à Xanthoma, juvenile xanthogranuloma
  • Warthin-finkeldey giant cells à measles
  • Aschoff giant cell à Rheumatic fever

Key Takeaways: Physiological giant cells include osteoclasts, syncytiotrophoblasts, and megakaryocytes. Aschoff cells are not physiological giant cells; they are associated with rheumatic fever. Other types of giant cells include Reed-Sternberg cells (Hodgkin's lymphoma), Touton giant cells (xanthoma), and Warthin-Finkeldey cells (measles).

questions.text: All are negative acute phase proteins, except:
questions.solution:
Acute phase proteins:-

They are class of plasma proteins which may increases or decreases in response to acute or chronic inflammation

2 types:

  1. Positive acute phase proteins
    • Proteins which increase in response to inflammation
    • C reactive protein
    • Fibrinogen
    • Plasminogen activator inhibitor
    • Serum amyloid A
    • Ferritin
    • Ceruloplasmin
  2. Negative acute phase proteins
    • Proteins which decrease in response to inflammation
    • Albumin
    • Prealbumin
    • Transferrin
    • Insulin like growth factor 1

Key Takeaways: Acute phase proteins are plasma proteins that change in response to inflammation. Positive acute phase proteins, like fibrinogen, increase during inflammation, while negative acute phase proteins, like albumin, transferrin, insulin-like growth factor 1, and prealbumin, decrease. Fibrinogen is a positive acute phase protein, not negative.

questions.text: Match the following.
questions.solution:
Durck's granulomaà seen in cerebral malaria (by plasmodium falciparum)

Stellate granuloma à Cat scratch disease, lymphogranuloma venerum, granuloma with central neutrophilic infiltrates

Doughnut granuloma à Q fever, Hodgkin's lymphoma, dense red fibrin ring with epithelioid macrophages

Eosinophilic granuloma à Churg Strauss syndrome

Key Takeaways:

  • Durck's granuloma is seen in cerebral malaria (Plasmodium falciparum).
  • Stellate granuloma is associated with cat scratch disease.
  • Doughnut granuloma is linked to Q fever.
  • Eosinophilic granuloma is seen in Churg Strauss syndrome.

choices.text: Alters the genetic locus of interest
Protein production is blocked by siRNA

questions.solution:
• GENE KNOCKING à this technique alters the genetic locus of interest by one-for-one substitution of DNA sequence information
  • Can be seen as a gain of function mutation
  • GENE KNOCKOUT à It is a process of cutting DNA- fragments from the gene using enzymes deleting the genetic information for a functioning protein.
  • Can be seen as a loss of function mutation
  • GENE KNOCKDOWN à in this technique, protein production is blocked by using particular substances e.g. microRNAs Or siRNA (small interfering RNA)

Key Takeaways: Gene knockout is the process of cutting DNA fragments from a gene using enzymes to delete genetic information for a functioning protein, resulting in a loss of function mutation. This differs from gene knocking, which involves altering the genetic locus, and gene knockdown, where protein production is blocked using substances like siRNA.

Reference: https://search.app/3P4yfThN9ueyoeQV7

questions.text: Pleuripotency of embryonic stem cell depends on all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
• Pleuripotency of embryonic stem cell depends on expression of following 4 transcription factors:
    1. Oct ¾
    2. Sox 2
    3. Kfl 4
    4. C-myc
  • Induced pleuripotent stem cells (IPS cells) à produced by "reprogramming " adult differentiated cells through transduction of genes encoding embryonic stem cell transcription factors.
  • They can generate cells of all 3 germ layers
  • It can repair damaged tissues and may replace congenitally defective cells.

Key Takeaways: The pluripotency of embryonic stem cells depends on the expression of four key transcription factors: Oct 3/4, Sox2, Klf4, and c-Myc. N-Myc is not involved in pluripotency. Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) are created by reprogramming adult cells with these transcription factors, allowing them to generate cells from all three germ layers and repair damaged tissues.

questions.text: With the help of which of the following cytokine, macrophages are converted to epithelioid cells?
questions.solution:
IFN-gamma is a cytokine that activates macrophages, converting them into epithelioid cells, which are characteristic of granulomatous inflammation. These epithelioid cells are macrophages that have undergone a morphological transformation and are involved in the formation of granulomas.

Why the other options are incorrect:-

  • a) TNF-alpha: While TNF-alpha plays a role in inflammation and granuloma formation, it is not directly responsible for converting macrophages to epithelioid cells.
  • c) TGF-beta: This cytokine is involved in fibrosis and tissue repair but does not specifically induce macrophages to become epithelioid cells.
  • d) IL-2: IL-2 is mainly involved in T-cell proliferation and activation, not in the conversion of macrophages to epithelioid cells.

Key Takeaways:

  • IFN-gamma activates macrophages and drives their differentiation into epithelioid cells, which are essential for granulomatous inflammation.
  • TNF-alpha, TGF-beta, and IL-2 play other roles in inflammation but are not involved in this specific process.

questions.text: Lipoxins synthesized from arachidonic acid act by
questions.solution:
• Lipoxins are generated from arachidonic acid by the lipoxygenase pathway, but unlike prostaglandins and leukotrienes, the lipoxins suppress inflammation by inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium.
  • They are unusual in that two cell populations are required for the transcellular biosynthesis of these mediators.
  • Neutrophils synthesize precursors of active lipoxins and pass these to platelets, where they are converted to mature lipoxins

Key Takeaways: Lipoxins, synthesized from arachidonic acid via the lipoxygenase pathway, decrease leukocyte migration, adhesion, and chemotaxis, helping to suppress inflammation. Unlike prostaglandins and leukotrienes, which promote inflammation, lipoxins reduce neutrophil activity. Their synthesis involves two cell types: neutrophils produce precursors, which are converted into mature lipoxins by platelets.

questions.text: Basement membrane degeneration is mediated by
questions.solution:
Matrix metalloproteinases (MMP)

  • The degradation of collagens and other ECM components is accomplished by a family of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), so called because they are dependent on metal ions (e.g., zinc) for their activity.
  • MMPs include interstitial collagenases (MMP-1, MMP-2, and MMP-3), which cleave fibrillar collagen; gelatinases, which degrade amorphous collagen and fibronectin; and stromelysins, which degrade a variety of ECM constituents, including proteoglycans, laminin, fibronectin, and amorphous collagen.
  • MMPs are produced by a variety of cell types (fibroblasts, Macrophages, neutrophils, synovial cells, and some epithelial cells), and their synthesis and secretion are regulated by growth factors, cytokines, and other agents.
  • The activity of the MMPs is tightly controlled.
  • They are produced as inactive precursors (zymogens) that must be first activated; this is accomplished by proteases (e.g., plasmin) likely to be present only at sites of injury.
  • Activated collagenases can be rapidly inhibited by specific tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMPs), produced by most mesenchymal cells.
  • During scar formation, MMPs are activated to remodel the deposited ECM, and then their activity is shut down by the TIMPs.

Key Takeaways: Basement membrane degeneration is mediated by matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), enzymes that degrade ECM components like collagens. MMPs are activated at injury sites and regulated by tissue inhibitors (TIMPs) to control remodeling during tissue repair.
